intro: Rubus niveus var. micranthus, commonly known as the white bramble, is a species of flowering plant in the Rosaceae family. It is characterized by its thorny stems and clusters of small, white flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant produces small, tart berries that are often used in culinary applications. It thrives in temperate climates and is typically found in woodlands and along stream banks. Its leaves are trifoliate, with a soft, hairy texture that distinguishes it from other Rubus species.
